commentBody:
My comment is on the following example from the Jan. 26 post:

"Last fall, Geoffrey Marcy, a prominent astronomer at Berkeley resigned after he was found guilty of sexually harassing students in a campus investigation.

Put the prepositional phrase “in a campus investigation” next to what it modifies (“found guilty”)."

There should be a comma after the word Berkeley, because "a prominent astronomer at Berkeley" is an appositive and the sentence would be clearly written without "a prominent astronomer at Berkeley." (A phrase that is nonessential to the meaning of the sentence requires TWO commas to set it off.) That second comma helps the reader.
